abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Financial Sector
            Adjustment Credit in Guinea is considered unsatisfactory
            with poor performance by both the Bank and the Borrower and
            uncertain sustainability. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project: a) to ensure successful implementation, a
            project has to be kept simple, well focused and have well
            identified priorities; b) the capacity of the borrower to
            implement a project should be correctly assessed and
            measures to reinforce it, if needed, taken well before
            project effectiveness; c) a thorough participatory approach
            in project preparation is paramount to ensure project
            ownership, understanding of its objectives, and proper
            identification of potential implementation problems; d)
            reform of the judicial system alone will not achieve any
            significant results, without proof of government enforcment
            the laws and elimination of corruption; e) an adjustment
            operation, due to its short duration, is not a suitable
            vehicle to address judicial system reforms; and f)
            restructuring and recapitilizing troubled banks without
            changing their ownership is a bad idea because it does not
            deal with the cause of the problems.
